Summary: The proposal aims to bridge the gap between correlation and causation in AI by developing structured latent variable models (SLVMs) that combine deep learning with causal graphical models. The method includes identifiable latent causal models, scalable inference with causal regularization, and counterfactual generation via latent interventions. The experiment plan covers synthetic, semi-synthetic, and real-world datasets, with validation against known biological pathways and expert-annotated counterfactual datasets.
Strengths: Addresses a critical and timely problem in AI research.
Proposes a novel combination of structured latent variable models and causal inference.
Comprehensive experimental validation plan with diverse datasets and tasks.
Clear articulation of the problem statement and motivation.
Ambitious hypothesis combining deep learning and causal graphical models.
Weaknesses: Feasibility concerns, especially with high-dimensional real-world data.
Lacks detailed discussion on computational constraints and potential failure modes.
Overly optimistic about the scalability and robustness of the proposed method.
Limited discussion on how to handle noisy or incomplete data in real-world scenarios.
Uncertainty about the robustness of the proposed method in complex real-world scenarios.
Questions: How will the method handle noisy or incomplete data in real-world applications?
What are the computational limits of the proposed scalable inference?
How will the model ensure robustness against adversarial or out-of-distribution inputs?
What are the fallback mechanisms if the latent variables fail to disentangle as hypothesized?
How will the proposed method handle the computational cost of the DAG penalty in high-dimensional settings?
Limitations: High computational cost for high-dimensional data.
Reliance on synthetic and semi-synthetic data for initial validation.
Limited discussion on interpretability and explainability of the inferred causal structures.
Scalability to very high-dimensional data is uncertain.
